title: Bujanovac
text:
Bujanovac (, ; ) is a <a href="List%20of%20cities%20in%20Serbia">town</a> and <a href="Municipalities%20and%20cities%20of%20Serbia">municipality</a> located in the <a href="P%C4%8Dinja%20District">Pčinja District</a> of southern <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a>. Situated in the <a href="South%20Morava">South Morava</a> basin, it is located in the geographical area known as <a href="Pre%C5%A1evo%20Valley">Preševo Valley</a>. It is also known for its source of mineral water and spa town "Bujanovačka banja".
<a href="Serbs">Serbs</a> are traditionally the largest ethnic group in the town, while the largest ethnic group in the municipality are <a href="Albanians%20in%20Serbia">Albanians</a>.
History.
Ancient history.
<a href="Kale-Kr%C5%A1evica">Kale-Krševica</a>, located south of <a href="Ristovac">Ristovac</a>, is an archaeological site of a 5th-century BC Ancient city of <a href="Macedon">Macedon</a>, thought to be <a href="Damastion">Damastion</a>. The <a href="Thracians">Thracian</a> <a href="Triballi">Triballi</a> and <a href="Paeonian">Paeonian</a> <a href="Agrianes">Agrianes</a> dwelled in the region, with the <a href="Scordisci">Scordisci</a> settling here after the <a href="Gallic%20invasion%20of%20the%20Balkans">Gallic invasion of the Balkans</a> in 279 BC. The region was conquered by the <a href="Ancient%20Rome">Romans</a> after 75 BC. It became part of the Roman propraetorial province <a href="Moesia">Moesia</a> in 29 BC (imperial from 27 BC). In 87 AD the region was re-organized into the <a href="Moesia">Moesia Superior</a>, which was a province of the <a href="Roman%20Empire">Roman Empire</a>.
Medieval Serbian era.
<a href="Serbia%20in%20the%20Middle%20Ages">Medieval Serbian state</a> like the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Serbia%20%28medieval%29">Kingdom of Serbia</a> or the <a href="Serbian%20Empire">Serbian Empire</a> included part of this region in the 12th century and most of it until the 14th century. Since the 15th century, the region was under Ottoman administration.
Ottoman era.
It became part of <a href="Rumelia">Rumelia</a>, as a historical term describing the area now referred to as the <a href="Balkans">Balkans</a> or the <a href="Balkan%20Peninsula">Balkan Peninsula</a> when it was administrated by the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>.
After the <a href="Congress%20of%20Berlin">Berlin agreement</a>, signed in 1878, there were some administrative changes in the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. Bujanovac – then "Buyanofça" – and its surroundings became part of the "Preševo area" of the Priština District and in 1905–1912 Bujanovac belonged to the 2nd category of borough covering 28 villages. After the <a href="Balkan%20Wars">Balkan Wars</a>, the area belonged to Kumanovo District of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Serbia">Kingdom of Serbia</a>.
Yugoslavia (1918–92).
After the establishment of the <a href="Kingdom%20of%20Serbs%2C%20Croats%20and%20Slovenians">Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenians</a>, in 1918, Bujanovac became part of Vranje Oblast, which was formed in 1921 after the <a href="Vidovdan%20Constitution">Vidovdan Constitution</a>. With administrative changes in 1929, it became part of <a href="Vardar%20Banovina">Vardar Banovina</a>, with the town of <a href="Skopje">Skopje</a> as capital. With the forming of <a href="Democratic%20Federal%20Yugoslavia">Democratic Federal Yugoslavia</a>, it was part of <a href="Socialist%20Republic%20of%20Serbia">Socialist Republic of Serbia</a> from 1943 to 1992. After <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, in 1947, Bujanovac was established as one of 117 municipalities of <a href="Central%20Serbia">Central Serbia</a>, under its own name.
From 1945 until 1992 Bujanovac was part of <a href="Socialist%20Republic%20of%20Serbia">Socialist Republic of Serbia</a>, within <a href="SFR%20Yugoslavia">SFR Yugoslavia</a>.
Breakup of Yugoslavia (1991–99).
In 1992, the <a href="Albanians%20in%20Serbia">Albanians</a> in the area organized a <a href="referendum">referendum</a> in which they voted that Bujanovac, <a href="Pre%C5%A1evo">Preševo</a> and <a href="Medve%C4%91a">Medveđa</a> should join the self-declared assembly of the <a href="Republic%20of%20Kosova">Republic of Kosova</a>. However, no major events happened until the end of the 1990s.
Following the <a href="breakup%20of%20Yugoslavia">breakup of Yugoslavia</a>, and nearby <a href="Kosovo%20War">Kosovo War</a> which lasted until 1999, between 1999 and 2001, an ethnic Albanian <a href="paramilitary">paramilitary</a> separatist organization, the <a href="Liberation%20Army%20of%20Pre%C5%A1evo%2C%20Medve%C4%91a%20and%20Bujanovac">UÇPMB</a>, raised an armed <a href="insurgency%20in%20the%20Pre%C5%A1evo%20Valley">insurgency in the Preševo Valley</a>, in the region mostly inhabited by Albanians, with a goal to occupy these three municipalities from Serbia and join them to the self-proclaimed <a href="Republic%20of%20Kosova">Republic of Kosova</a>.
Unlike in the case of Kosovo, western countries condemned the attacks and described it as the "extremism" and use of "illegal terrorist actions" by the group. Following the <a href="overthrow%20of%20Slobodan%20Milo%C5%A1evi%C4%87">overthrow of Slobodan Milošević</a>, the new Yugoslav government suppressed the violence by 2001 and defeated the separatists. <a href="NATO">NATO</a> troops also helped the Yugoslav government by ensuring that the rebels do not import the conflicts back into Kosovo. Thereafter, the situation has stabilized even though large number of forces exist in this small municipality.
In 2009, Serbia opened a military base <a href="Cepotina">Cepotina</a> five kilometers south of Bujanovac, to further stabilize the area.
Modern.
Today, Bujanovac is located in the <a href="P%C4%8Dinja%20District">Pčinja District</a> of southern Serbia.
On 7 March 2017, the <a href="President%20of%20Albania">President of Albania</a> <a href="Bujar%20Nishani">Bujar Nishani</a> made a historical visit to the municipalities of Bujanovac and Preševo, in which <a href="Albanians%20in%20Serbia">Albanians</a> form the ethnic majority.
Settlements.
Aside from the town of Bujanovac, the municipality includes the following settlements:
Demographics.
According to the 2002 census, the municipality of Bujanovac had a population of 43,302 people. Most of the municipality population live in rural areas, with only 27.74% living in the urban parts. The municipality of Bujanovac has 59 inhabited places.
Ethnic groups.
The majority of the municipality population according to the 2002 census are <a href="Albanians%20in%20Serbia">Albanians</a>, encompassing 54.69% of the total population. During the 2011 census, undercounting of the census units, owing to the boycott by most of the members of the Albanian ethnic community in the municipality of Bujanovac, was reported. The ethnic composition of the municipality is as follows:
Culture and society.
Sports.
Bujanovac has a number of <a href="association%20football">football</a> teams, the most notable being BSK Bujanovac, Kf Tërnoci and KF Besa.
